docs.lead_paragraph: More than 900,000 elderly and disabled people will soon be dropped by health maintenance organizations pulling out of the Medicare program, the Clinton administration said today. The number, which is substantially greater than estimates last month by the H.M.O. industry, underlines the turbulence and instability of the market in which Medicare beneficiaries seek private health insurance.

headline.main: Estimate of Ousters by H.M.O.'s Is Raised

docs.abstract: Clinton administration says more than 900,000 elderly and disabled people will soon be dropped by health maintenance organizations pulling out of Medicare program; number, substantially greater than recent estimates by HMO industry, underscores turbulence and instability of market in which Medicare beneficiaries seek private health insurance (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Insurance regulators in Florida have placed a subsidiary of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York under special supervision and given the subsidiary until tomorrow to come up with a plan to cover a $4.8 million shortfall in its reserves. As a result, HIP officials said they had stepped up negotiations to seek a cash infusion from another health company that might want to form a joint venture with the subsidiary, HIP Health Plan of Florida.

headline.main: Florida Regulators Step In to Oversee a Troubled H.M.O. Unit

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying that the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee appeared to be dragging his feet, Democrats urged him today to take action on his own proposal to establish prescription drug benefits under Medicare. In a letter to the chairman, Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, Democrats on the committee prodded him to convene the panel ''as early as possible, perhaps before the August recess,'' to vote on legislation adding drug benefits to Medicare.

headline.main: Senate Democrats Push Finance Chairman to Act on Prescription Drug Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans warn of the dangers of a big ''one size fits all'' prescription drug program for the elderly, run by the heavy hand of government bureaucrats. Democrats rail against the prospect of elderly Americans at the mercy of profit-hungry pharmaceutical companies, and scoff at Republican efforts to provide drug coverage through the private sector. For months now, pollsters and strategists in both parties have been testing and honing these arguments, knowing that the cost of prescription drugs -- and the lack of Medicare coverage for them -- is one of the most powerful issues of this election year. But as the recent drug bill passed by House Republicans underscored, many analysts say, all the positioning comes down to an old philosophical division between the parties: How big a role should the government play in providing health care? How much should be left to the private sector?

headline.main: Political Battle Lines Are Clearly Drawn in Fight Over Medicare Drug Coverage

docs.abstract: Pollsters and strategists in both major parties are testing and honing arguments for and against low-cost prescription drug program for elderly, which has become one of most powereful issues of election year; many analysts say positioning comes down to old philosophical division between parties, related to how big a role government should play in providing health care and how much should be left to private sector (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a disturbing, almost willfully irresponsible quality to the giddy rush by politicians to enact huge federal tax cuts without regard to how much of the projected surpluses are real, and with little or no debate about other, better ways in which some of that money might be used. It's as if very little was learned during those long years of wandering in the debilitating environs of big budget deficits. Now surpluses are blossoming in the midst of a campaign season and the politicians seem determined to devour them with immediate and mindless tax cuts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pharmaceuticals are a risky, but lucrative, business. Drug companies turn scientific advances into life-saving medicines that can generate millions of dollars in sales each day, but the process takes time -- an average of 12 to 15 years -- and money. Through a recent wave of mergers and acquisitions, the prescription drug industry is increasingly global. But the companies earn most of their profits, and do most of their basic research, in the United States, the last drug market free of price restraints. The industry consistently ranks as the most profitable among Fortune 500 companies.

headline.main: In a Drug's Journey to Market, Discovery Is Just the First of Many Steps

docs.abstract: Article describes long process by which drug comes to market: from discovery, to clinical testing, to getting regulators' approval, to patenting, to generic competition; graphs (L)

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and JEFF GERTH

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR all the curative powers of a booming economy, the overflowing prosperity of the last four years has failed to raise the second-class incomes of the one-third of American adults who have not gone beyond high school. Just as near-universal high school education was one of the great achievements of 20th-century America, politicians and business leaders have long sought to lure more students to college, reasoning that the college-educated would earn more in a ''new economy'' that now more than ever rewards a bachelor's degree. College, they believed, could help close the gap between the economic haves and have nots. Yet the proportion of Americans who have only a high school diploma has barely budged for 30 years, through good times and bad.

headline.main: The Nation: The Classroom Ceiling; Making Sense of a Stubborn Education Gap

docs.abstract: Booming economy has created tight labor market that has driven wages for everyone up faster than inflation, but income gap between college graduates and workers without college has widened rather than narrowed; moreover, proportion of Americans who have only high-school diploma has remained steady at about one-third for 30 years; photos, graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you have set foot on a subway platform during the last 20 years, there is a decent chance he has been standing there next to you, a small, smiling man in no hurry to catch a train. He was probably carrying a green satchel with a tiny American flag stitched on the flap. From this satchel, he probably produced a pair of junk store binoculars or a cheap camera and pointed them in the direction of a rust-stained wall that seemed to warrant neither close inspection nor documentation.
docs.abstract: Article on New York City subway buffs Philip Ashforth Coppola, who is devoting rest of his life to writing and publishing exhaustive, multivolume history of design and decoration of all 496 stations that ever existed in New York City subway system, Paul Kronenberg, who has mock-up of motorman's cab in his Brooklyn apartment, Derek Nisbett, who collects model subway cars, and David Pirmann, who runs subway Web site; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: When you first think about it, it's a no-brainer. When the final stages of mapping the human genome were hyped last month, both President Bill Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair called for a swift, extensive ban on using genetic information to discriminate in employment or insurance. Clinton had already signed an executive order back in February, banning such discrimination for federal employees. True to form, both politicians had polling data to support them. A 1998 survey of 1,000 randomly selected Americans found that 63 percent of them balked at any genetic testing if an employer or health insurer could have access to the data. So a ban on genetic discrimination not only secures privacy and fairness; it also protects good research by reassuring study volunteers that the information they provide is in completely safe hands. What's not to like? Well, quite a lot, actually. Like most notions that command almost universal assent, the proposed ban on genetic discrimination makes far less sense the more you think about it. A few brave souls, like the writer Michael Kinsley, have pointed this out, but even he admitted that he wasn't sure what conclusion to draw. So here goes: genetic discrimination, however troubling, is both rational and inevitable. And the sooner we get over our hand-wringing, the better.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 7-23-00: Counter Culture; Promotion of the Fittest

docs.abstract: Andrew Sullivan article rejects the arguments against genetic testing by employers and health insurers, who presumably would discriminate against people on the basis of their DNA; says that while the point of laws against racial bias is to outlaw irrational discrimination based on irrelevant characteristics, barring genetic discrimination would be outlawing rational bias based on relevant information; drawing (L)
